title: Data-Constrained Synthesis of Training Data for De-Identification
author: Thomas Vakili (Stockholm University), Aron Henriksson (Stockholm University), Hercules Dalianis (Stockholm University)
background: This study focuses on generating synthetic datasets to train Named Entity Recognition (NER) models for detecting personally identifiable information (PII) in clinical text, addressing the challenges posed by data scarcity and privacy concerns.
contribution: This paper introduces the synthesis of training data for NER models to solve the problem of data scarcity in the clinical domain, achieving only a small drop in predictive performance when using synthetic data.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily emphasize achieving the highest model performance or assessing privacy of synthetic text, often requiring large datasets.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by demonstrating that effective NER models can be developed with minimal domain adaptation data and leveraging machine-annotated synthetic corpora.

key_innovation: The approach combines domain-adapted generative models with machine annotations to create high-utility PII detection models using constrained resources.
real_world_impact: This research contributes to the practical application of synthetic data in healthcare, helping institutions improve their privacy-preserving capabilities without jeopardizing sensitive patient information.
limitations: The authors mention that the effectiveness may vary according to the quality of the machine annotator and the specific tasks involved.

new_terms.de-identification: **De-identification** refers to the process of removing or obscuring personal information from datasets to protect individuals' privacy.
new_terms.synthetic datasets: **Synthetic datasets** are artificially generated data that mimic the statistical properties of real datasets, used to train models when original data cannot be shared.
